evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, specifically in the hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim phase.

assumptions: The observed pushback events and communication attempts are representative of the hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim phase.
The communication between crew and headset operator is indicative of overall crew coordination.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing procedural errors, or if mechanical failure was the primary cause.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows active communication and coordination attempts but also a failure to stop at the TRP, indicating observable communication/coordination breakdown supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether the procedural deviation was due to communication breakdown or other factors like procedural deviation alone.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim data, such as timing, context, and crew interactions.

assumptions: The described crew interactions and timing in the evidence correspond directly to the key features referenced in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 data.
No mechanical or environmental factors primarily caused the event beyond what is described.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the pushback continuation beyond the TRP was due to environmental or marking deficiencies rather than crew communication breakdown.
If hardware or mechanical issues were identified as primary causes instead of coordination failures.

The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows trained personnel were present and involved in pushback, with the instructor taking over and performing the procedure, yet the aircraft moved beyond the TRP causing a deviation, supporting procedural deviation over communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of communication failure or environmental factors; ambiguity remains but evidence favors procedural deviation.

children_spec.statement: Relevant environmental data (weather, visibility, lighting) was unavailable or incomplete at the time of the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Check if weather reports, visibility records, and lighting conditions data exist and are accessible for the incident time

children_spec.statement: Marking information (signage, runway/taxiway markings) was not available or not properly documented
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify presence and completeness of marking documentation and physical evidence at the incident location

children_spec.statement: Communication or data systems providing environmental or marking information were unavailable or malfunctioning
children_spec.test_procedure: Review system logs and maintenance records for failures or outages of relevant communication or data systems

node.statement: Availability of required pushback equipment at the time of operation

assumptions: The pushback equipment was available and functional as no evidence suggests otherwise.
The crew followed standard communication protocols as indicated by headset operator and crew interactions.
defeaters: If evidence showed communication failures or coordination issues causing the deviation, or if equipment malfunction was documented, the conclusion might change.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the aircraft moved beyond the designated stop point, indicating procedural deviation. H2 and H3 show crew actions consistent with procedural handling rather than communication failure, supporting the procedural deviation hypothesis over communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of communication breakdown or equipment failure is present; ambiguity remains if other factors contributed.

node.statement: Crew attempted to communicate relevant information but failed to coordinate effectively

assumptions: The failure to stop at the TRP despite communication attempts indicates coordination failure.
No mechanical or environmental deficiencies primarily caused the incident.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective coordination and adherence to stop points despite communication attempts.
If mechanical or environmental factors were primary causes rather than communication breakdown.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H2 and H3 show active communication attempts between crew members, but H4 shows failure to stop at the TRP, indicating ineffective coordination despite communication, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication attempts were sufficient for effective coordination

node.statement: Relevant environmental data (weather, visibility, lighting) was unavailable or incomplete at the time of the incident

defeaters: If evidence showed missing or incomplete environmental data such as weather, visibility, or lighting conditions at the time of the incident.
If markings like the Tug release point were not visible or not present.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows communication and marking visibility were adequate, contradicting the claim that relevant environmental data was unavailable or incomplete.

node.statement: Communication devices and channels among crew were operational and accessible

defeaters: If evidence showed failed or inaccessible communication devices or channels among crew during the event.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H2, and H3 show that communication devices were operational and accessible among crew, contradicting the claim of communication breakdown.
